title: 107_hr4475
content: The Act titled "District of Columbia Tax Incentives Improvement Act of 2002" makes modifications to enterprise zone benefits available in the District of Columbia. The "District of Columbia Tax Incentives Improvement Act of 2002" designates the District of Columbia as an empowerment zone, treating it as such under the Internal Revenue Code. This amendment includes conforming adjustments to the code. The District of Columbia is designated as an empowerment zone under the Internal Revenue Code, with adjustments made to the code for the DC Zone. This includes a special rule for the application of the employment credit in the DC Zone. The Internal Revenue Code is amended for the District of Columbia, including changes to the capital gains exclusion period from 5 years to 2 years. The Internal Revenue Code for the District of Columbia is amended to change the capital gains exclusion period from 5 years to 2 years. Additionally, modifications are made to the definition of a DC Zone Business. The Internal Revenue Code for the District of Columbia is amended to change the capital gains exclusion period from 5 years to 2 years. A special rule for businesses holding intangibles in DC Zone businesses is outlined, requiring a certain percentage of employees and wages to be residents of the District of Columbia. These amendments are effective as if included in the Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997. SEC. 3 extends enterprise zone treatment in the Internal Revenue Code until December 31, 2009. It also amends the effective dates for economic development bonds and zero percent capital gains rates. SEC. 4 makes the first-time homebuyer credit for the District of Columbia permanent with other modifications. The first-time homebuyer credit for the District of Columbia is made permanent with modifications. Individuals can be treated as first-time homebuyers in the case of purchasing a residence due to a divorce or separation. The first-time homebuyer credit for the District of Columbia is made permanent with modifications. Individuals can be treated as first-time homebuyers in the case of purchasing a residence due to a divorce or separation. The credit allowed under subsection (a) for the taxable year shall not exceed the excess of the amount of tax. The amendment made by paragraph (1) shall apply to purchases after the date of the enactment of this Act. The first-time homebuyer credit for the District of Columbia is now permanent with changes. The credit allowed for the taxable year cannot exceed the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55, minus the credits allowable under subpart A of part IV of subchapter A and section 27. Any excess credit can be carried over to the following taxable year. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to Section 1400C of the Code. The amendment changes subsections (h) and (i) to (g) and (h) respectively, effective for taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. EXPANSION OF TAX-EXEMPT ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT BONDS. Amendment to Section 1400A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to read as follows: "SEC. 1400A. TAX-EXEMPT ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT BONDS." In the District of Columbia Enterprise Zone, certain provisions regarding bonds are exempted, including limitations on bond amounts and employee residency requirements. Bonds exempted under this section are not considered private activity bonds. This provision applies to bonds issued between January 1, 1998, and December 31, 2009, with amendments effective for bonds issued after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6. Bonds issued by the District of Columbia are exempt from state and local taxes, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001.
